title: 2644 Victor Jara
text:
2644 Victor Jara, provisional designation , is an <a href="asteroid">asteroid</a> from the inner regions of the <a href="asteroid%20belt">asteroid belt</a>, approximately in diameter. It was discovered on 22 September 1973, by Soviet-Russian astronomer <a href="Nikolai%20Chernykh">Nikolai Chernykh</a> at the <a href="Crimean%20Astrophysical%20Observatory">Crimean Astrophysical Observatory</a> in Nauchnij, on the Crimean peninsula. It was named after Chilean singer and composer <a href="V%C3%ADctor%20Jara">Víctor Jara</a>.
Orbit and classification.
"Victor Jara" is a non-<a href="Asteroid%20family">family</a> asteroid of the main belt's <a href="Background%20asteroid">background population</a>. It orbits the Sun in the <a href="Kirkwood%20gap">inner</a> main-belt at a distance of 1.8–2.5 <a href="Astronomical%20unit">AU</a> once every 3 years and 2 months (1,168 days; <a href="semi-major%20axis">semi-major axis</a> of 2.17 AU). Its orbit has an <a href="orbital%20eccentricity">eccentricity</a> of 0.17 and an <a href="orbital%20inclination">inclination</a> of 3<a href="Degree%20%28angle%29">°</a> with respect to the <a href="ecliptic">ecliptic</a>.
The body's <a href="observation%20arc">observation arc</a> begins with a <a href="precovery">precovery</a> taken at the <a href="Palomar%20Observatory">Palomar Observatory</a> in April 1954, or nearly 20 years prior to its official discovery observation.
Physical characteristics.
Diameter and albedo.
According to the survey carried out by the <a href="NEOWISE">NEOWISE</a> mission of NASA's <a href="Wide-field%20Infrared%20Survey%20Explorer">Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer</a>, "Victor Jara" measures 5.914 kilometers in diameter and its surface has an <a href="astronomical%20albedo">albedo</a> of 0.153.
Rotation period.
As of 2018, no rotational <a href="lightcurve">lightcurve</a> of "Victor Jara" has been obtained from <a href="Photometry%20%28astronomy%29">photometric</a> observations. The body's <a href="rotation%20period">rotation period</a>, <a href="Poles%20of%20astronomical%20bodies">pole</a> and shape remain unknown.
Naming.
This <a href="minor%20planet">minor planet</a> was named by the discoverer after Chilean folk singer and activist <a href="V%C3%ADctor%20Jara">Víctor Jara</a>, who was assassinated on 16 September 1973, just six days prior to the planet's discovery. The official naming citation was published by the <a href="Minor%20Planet%20Center">Minor Planet Center</a> on 15 May 1984 ().
Víctor Jara, a prominent communist political activist in Chile, toured the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a> in the 1960s and praised its culture, its scientific achievements and the friendliness of its working people. He was tortured and murdered shortly after the <a href="1973%20Chilean%20coup%20d%27%C3%A9tat">1973 Chilean coup d'état</a> led by Army Commander-in-Chief Augusto Pinochet, that ended the government of the socialist <a href="Salvador%20Allende%20Gossens">Salvador Allende</a>.
